content:
Overweight and obesity are characterized by an accumulation of excess body fat associated with the risk of developing weight-related complications. Multiple underlying factors (e.g., genetics, hormonal changes, lifestyle behaviors, medical conditions, medication use) ultimately result in prolonged excess energy intake relative to energy expenditure. Body mass index (BMI) and waist circumference are used to diagnose and classify overweight and obesity, and to estimate the risk of weight-related complications. Clinical evaluation and diagnostic studies are used to assess for contributing causes of overweight and obesity and weight-related complications (e.g., hypertension, cardiovascular disease, dyslipidemia, diabetes). Management focuses on weight loss and preventing or improving weight-related complications, and should be individualized based on shared decision-making. Management options include lifestyle changes (dietary changes, increased physical activity, and/or behavioral interventions), pharmacotherapy, and bariatric surgery. Interventions are often performed concurrently.

  • Sex: ♀ > ♂
  • Prevalence (adults)
    • Overweight: ∼ 30% [1]
    • Obesity (all classes): ∼ 40% [1][2]
    • Class 3 obesity: ∼ 9% [1][2]

Epidemiological data refers to the US, unless otherwise specified.

Overweight and obesity are caused by prolonged excess energy intake relative to energy expenditure. Contributing factors include: [3][4][5]

  • Genetic and epigenetic predisposition
    • Genes that regulate appetite and satiety, genetic syndromes [4]
    • Maternal obesity during pregnancy [4]
  • Excessive caloric intake
    • High-calorie foods and unhealthy eating habits
    • Dysregulated eating: emotional eating, eating disorders (e.g., binge-eating disorder) [5][6]
  • Low caloric expenditure: sedentary lifestyle, excessive screen use, physical inactivity [4]
  • Socioeconomic factors: food insecurity, social determinants of health
  • Hormonal conditions: hypothyroidism, hypercortisolism
  • Medications: corticosteroids, antipsychotics, anticonvulsants, antidepressants, antihyperglycemics [5][7]

Chronic sleep deprivation can lead to obesity through multiple mechanisms (e.g., increased caloric intake, sedentary lifestyle, and hormonal imbalance). [4][5]

Body mass index [6][8][9][10]

Lower cut-offs for BMI are used in individuals of Asian descent. [8][9][10][11]

BMI classification for overweight and obesity [6][8][9][10]
Adults (absolute BMI) Children aged ≥ 2 years (BMI percentile for age and sex) [4][12]
Overweight
  • Most populations: 25–29.9 kg/m2
  • Asian descent: 23–24.9 kg/m2 [13][14]
  • 85th–94th percentile
Class 1 obesity
  • Most populations: 30–34.9 kg/m2
  • Asian descent: 25–29.9 kg/m2 [13][14]
  • 100–119% of the 95th percentile
Class 2 obesity
  • Most populations: 35–39.9 kg/m2
  • Asian descent: 30–34.9 kg/m2
  • 120–139% of the 95th percentile
Class 3 obesity
  • Most populations: ≥ 40 kg/m2
  • Asian descent: ≥ 35 kg/m2
  • ≥ 140% of the 95th percentile

There is a direct relationship between increasing BMI and increasing risk of ASCVD, type 2 diabetes (T2DM), and all-cause mortality. [15]

To determine class 2 or class 3 obesity in children, use the adult BMI cutoff if it is lower than the pediatric BMI percentile for age and sex cutoff. [4]

Clinical severity

Clinical severity assessment tools for obesity may be used for risk stratification based on the presence and severity of weight-related complications. Examples of tools include:

  • Lancet Diabetes and Endocrinology Commission framework for differentiating preclinical from clinical obesity [16]
  • American Association of Clinical Endocrinologists and American College of Endocrinology (AACE/ACE) system for staging adiposity-based chronic disease. [6]
  • Characteristic findings
    • Increased BMI [6]
    • Increased waist circumference [6]
  • Associated features [16]
    • Fatigue and poor exercise tolerance
    • Body pains
    • Reduced functional mobility (may negatively impact activities of daily living)
    • Clinical features of weight-related complications

Overweight and obesity in children and overweight and obesity in pregnancy (including preconception care) are addressed separately.

Approach [3][6][15][17]

  • Assess BMI classification for overweight and obesity, typically at routine health maintenance visits.
  • Confirm that the elevated BMI represents excess adiposity. [6][16]
  • Perform a clinical evaluation and routine studies in all patients to assess for:
    • Causes of excess adiposity
    • Weight-related complications, including metabolic syndrome
  • Determine the clinical severity of obesity.
  • Perform additional studies in select patients as indicated.

Screening for metabolic syndrome is performed as part of the clinical evaluation and routine studies in patients with obesity. [6]

Clinical evaluation for overweight and obesity [3][6][18]

Address any acute problems and obtain the patient's permission before discussing weight. [19][20][21]

History

  • Weight-related history: weight trends, prior attempts at weight loss
  • Personal or family history of weight-related complications
  • Medications associated with weight gain
  • Dietary habits and level of physical activity
  • Social determinants of health that may be barriers to a healthy diet and/or physical activity [19]
  • Experience of weight-related bias and stigma [19]

Review of symptoms

  • Sleep deprivation: insufficient sleep time, poor quality of sleep (e.g., clinical features of obstructive sleep apnea)
  • Symptoms of asthma
  • Symptoms of hypothyroidism
  • Back or joint pain
  • Clinical features of GERD
  • Psychological conditions: symptoms of depression, anxiety disorders, clinical features of eating disorders
  • Female patients: abnormal vaginal bleeding, infertility, urinary incontinence
  • Male patients: decreased libido, erectile dysfunction

Physical examination

  • Vital signs: to assess for bradycardia, tachycardia, elevated blood pressure
  • Waist circumference if BMI < 35 kg/m2: to assess for abdominal obesity and metabolic syndrome [6][15][22]
  • Thyroid examination: to assess for goiter or nodules
  • Skin examination: to assess for acanthosis nigricans , hirsutism, skin striae, intertrigo, signs of chronic venous insufficiency, acrochordons
  • Female patients: clinical features of PCOS
  • Male patients: clinical features of male hypogonadism

Use an appropriately sized blood pressure cuff; extended cuffs may be necessary. [13]

Studies for weight-related complications [3][6][18]

Routine studies

  • CBC
  • Liver chemistries
  • Fasting plasma glucose and hemoglobin A1C (see “Diagnostics for diabetes” for interpretation of results) [6][18][23][24]
  • Fasting lipid panel
  • TSH (in adults)
  • Consider: BMP (for electrolytes, BUN, and creatinine), urine albumin-to-creatinine ratio [16][18]

Further studies

Obtain further studies based on clinical suspicion for weight-related complications. Examples include:

  • Diagnostics for obstructive sleep apnea
  • Diagnostics for GERD
  • Diagnostics for PCOS
  • Diagnostics for amenorrhea
  • Diagnostics for male hypogonadism
  • Diagnostics for MASLD [3][4]

Overweight and obesity in children and overweight and obesity in pregnancy (including preconception care) are addressed separately.

Approach [3][6][13][15][16]

  • Provide collaborative patient-centered care. [19][20][21]
    • Address any acute problems and obtain the patient's permission before discussing weight.
    • Focus on specific health outcomes rather than BMI and weight alone.
    • Individualize management using shared decision-making.
  • Address modifiable risk factors, including:
    • Modifiable risk factors for cardiovascular disease
    • Underlying conditions or medications associated with weight gain [7]
  • Set weight goals.
    • Overweight without weight-related complications: maintain or lose weight (based on patient preference)
    • All other patients: Long-term weight loss of 5–15% is recommended.
  • Initiate appropriate interventions.
    • All patients: Recommend lifestyle modifications and refer to multidisciplinary specialists as needed.
    • Indications for weight-loss medications: Offer pharmacotherapy in addition to lifestyle modifications; use shared decision-making to determine treatment. [6][13][15][16][25]
    • Indications for bariatric surgery: Recommend a bariatric surgery evaluation.
  • Provide ongoing management.
    • Assess progress toward weight-loss goals and modify therapy as needed.
    • Periodically assess other medications for possible dose reduction. [13][15]
    • After long-term weight-loss goal is achieved: Recommend a weight maintenance program for ≥ 1 year. [6][13][25]

A trial of lifestyle modifications alone is not required before initiating pharmacotherapy in patients with indications for weight-loss medications. [13]

Even small weight losses (e.g., 3–5% of body weight) can decrease the risk of weight-related complications. [6][13][25]

Medications associated with weight changes

Medications associated with weight changes [3][5]
Promote weight gain Mild or no effect on weight gain May promote weight loss
Antihyperglycemic agents
  • Insulin
  • Sulfonylureas
  • Meglitinides
  • DPP-4 inhibitors
  • Metformin
  • GLP-1 agonists
  • SGLT-2 inhibitors
Antihypertensives
  • Beta blockers: atenolol, metoprolol, propanolol
  • Beta blockers: carvedilol, nebivolol
  • ACE inhibitors
  • Angiotensin receptor blockers
  • Calcium channel blockers
  • None
Antidepressants
  • SSRI: paroxetine
  • TCAs: amitriptyline, nortriptyline
  • Mirtazapine
  • SSRIs: fluoxetine, sertraline, citalopram, escitalopram
  • SNRIs: venlafaxine, duloxetine
  • TCA: imipramine
  • Bupropion
Antipsychotics and mood stabilizers
  • First-generation antipsychotics: clozapine, olanzapine, quetiapine, risperidone, brexpiprazole
  • First-generation antipsychotics: chlorpromazine, thioridazine
  • Lithium
  • Second-generation antipsychotics: aripiprazole, ziprasidone, paliperidone
  • First-generation antipsychotics: haloperidol
  • None
Anticonvulsants
  • Carbamazepine
  • Valproic acid
  • Gabapentin
  • Pregabalin
  • Lamotrigine
  • Levetiracetam
  • Phenytoin
  • Oxcarbazepine
  • Felbamate
  • Topiramate
  • Zonisamide
Contraceptives
  • Injectable progestins
  • Combined oral contraceptives
  • Intrauterine devices
  • None
Anti-inflammatory agents
  • Corticosteroids
  • NSAIDs and DMARDs
  • None

General principles [3][6][7]

  • Lifestyle interventions can lead to weight loss, increase insulin sensitivity, and reduce cardiovascular risk factors. [15]
  • To support the implementation of dietary and physical activity changes:
    • Refer to a multicomponent behavioral intervention program.
    • Address barriers related to social determinants of health (e.g., food insecurity). [19]
  • Lifestyle modifications without pharmacotherapy
    • Advise patients on weight-loss goals.
      • Initial goal: ≥ 2.5% weight loss at 1 month [6]
      • Long-term goal: 5–10% weight loss at 6 months [13][15]
    • Base frequency of follow-up on patient need (e.g, every 4–6 weeks initially). [20]

Dietary changes [6][7][17]

  • Provide general counseling on nutrition.
  • Various dietary approaches that result in a caloric deficit may be effective for weight loss.
  • Refer to a dietitian for specific caloric and energy deficit recommendations. [6][7][15]

Physical activity [6][7][26][27]

  • Provide counseling on regular exercise.
    • No specific form of physical activity is recommended over another for weight loss.
    • Encourage gradually increasing quantity and/or intensity of activity as tolerated to meet recommendations and weight-loss goals. [26][27]
  • Encourage an increase in nonsedentary activities. [15]
  • Additional guidance: exercise coach or physical therapy referral

Behavioral interventions [6][7][17][25]

  • Offer referral for to a multicomponent behavioral intervention program, if available.
  • Interventions may include:
    • Goal setting
    • Self-monitoring of weight
    • Identification of weight-gain triggers
    • Development of self-management skills
    • Stress reduction and healthy coping skills
    • Support groups and psychological counseling (e.g., cognitive behavioral therapy, intensive behavioral therapy)
    • Counseling on sleep hygiene

General principles [5][13][15][25][28]

  • Offer pharmacotherapy in conjunction with lifestyle modifications to patients with indications for weight-loss medications:
    • BMI ≥ 30 kg/m2
    • BMI ≥ 27 kg/m2 and at least one weight-related complication
  • Choose a medication based on indications, contraindications, and patient preference.
  • Titrate medications gradually to improve tolerance.
  • Weight-loss goals
    • Initial: ≥ 5% from baseline at 3 months on maximum tolerated dose [15][25]
    • Long-term: ≥ 5–15% from baseline [6][13]
  • Follow-up
    • Frequency: monthly for 3–6 months, and then less frequently [7][13][15]
    • Monitor for adverse effects, including cholelithiasis and mood disorders. [6]
    • Weight-loss goals not met: Consider changing to an alternative medication and/or referral to an obesity specialist.
    • Long-term use of medications is typically required for sustained weight loss.

Medications

Pharmacotherapy for weight loss [5][13][15][25][28]
Drug class Examples Indications Considerations
Nutrient-stimulated hormone-based medications
  • Tirzepatide [28]
  • Semaglutide [25]
  • Liraglutide [25]
  • Most patients, especially those with T2DM and/or HFpEF: tirzepatide or semaglutide [7][29]
  • Advise patients on management strategies for common GI side effects.
  • Restart dose titration if 2–3 consecutive doses are missed. [13][30]
  • Monitor for adverse effects (e.g., pancreatitis, gallbadder disease, malnutrition, and sarcopenia). [30]
Centrally acting medications
  • For long-term use
    • Naltrexone/bupropion extended release [25]
    • Phentermine/topiramate extended release [25]
  • For use ≤ 12 weeks
    • Phentermine [25]
    • Diethylpropion [25]
  • Depression and/or desire for smoking cessation: Consider naltrexone/bupropion.
  • Migraines: Consider phentermine/topiramate.
  • Periodically monitor blood pressure and heart rate.
  • Check state laws for prescribing requirements for phentermine and diethylpropion.
  • Phentermine/topiramate must be tapered when discontinuing. [25]
Lipase inhibitors
  • Orlistat
  • Not routinely recommended; may be selected based on patient preference [25]
  • Advise patients to:
    • Take with meals containing fat.
    • Take a daily multivitamin including fat-soluble vitamins (2 hours apart from taking orlistat).

Due to the teratogenicity risk, advise patients who can become pregnant to use contraception while taking pharmacotherapy for obesity. [7][25][31]

Tirzepatide has the highest efficacy in terms of total weight loss compared to other weight-loss drugs. [13]

Orlistat reversibly inhibits gastric and pancreatic lipase, resulting in a decrease in fat breakdown and absorption, and can cause gastrointestinal side effects.

  • Indications for bariatric surgery [32]
    • Class 2 obesity or class 3 obesity
    • Class 1 obesity with either of the following:
      • T2DM
      • Lack of improvement following nonsurgical interventions
  • Average weight loss with bariatric surgery: > 20% [7][13]
  • See “Metabolic and bariatric surgery” for additional information.

Cardiometabolic weight-related complications [6][15][33][34]

  • Hypertension, cardiovascular disease (ASCVD)
  • Cardiomyopathy and congestive heart failure [35][36]
  • Insulin resistance: prediabetes, T2DM
  • Dyslipidemia
  • PCOS
  • Nonalcoholic steatohepatitis: increased risk of liver cirrhosis and liver malignancy

The co-occurence of central obesity, T2DM or prediabetes, hypertension, and dyslipidemia is known as metabolic syndrome. [33]

Additional weight-related complications [6][15]

  • Respiratory
    • Obstructive sleep apnea (OSA)
    • Obesity hypoventilation syndrome
    • Asthma [6]
  • Musculoskeletal
    • Osteoarthritis
    • Chronic back pain [37]
    • Slipped capital femoral epiphysis and Blount disease (especially in children) [4]
  • Reproductive and genitourinary [38]
    • Adverse events during pregnancy: e.g., gestational hypertension, preterm labor, and pregnancy loss (see “Overweight and obesity in pregnancy”) [39]
    • Menstrual and ovulatory dysfunction
    • Female urinary incontinence
    • Infertility
    • Erectile dysfunction [40]
    • Male hypogonadism
  • Gastrointestinal [41]
    • Cholelithiasis
    • GERD
    • Colonic diverticulosis
  • Malignancies [42][43]
    • Hepatocellular carcinoma
    • Colorectal cancer
    • Breast cancer
    • Endometrial cancer
    • Renal cancer [44]
  • Psychological [19]
    • Anxiety
    • Depression
    • Decreased quality of life
  • Other
    • Increased all-cause mortality
    • Idiopathic intracranial hypertension [4]
    • Thromboembolic complications, including portal vein thrombosis [45][46]
    • Chronic renal insufficiency [35]
    • Dementia [47]
    • Gout [48]

We list the most important complications. The selection is not exhaustive.

  • All patients
    • Provide counseling on nutrition and counseling on regular exercise at each routine wellness visit.
    • Recommend avoidance of weight gain to prevent weight-related complications.
  • Patients with overweight or normal weight with a history of overweight or obesity
    • Recommend self-monitoring of weight.
    • Recommend lifestyle interventions for overweight and obesity if weight is trending up.
  • See also “Primary prevention strategies for adult health.”

Overweight and obesity in children [4]

  • Children with overweight or obesity are at increased risk of obesity and weight-related complications as adults.
  • Prevalence of obesity in individuals 12–19 years of age: ∼ 20% [49]

Diagnostics

  • Assess BMI at all well-child visits in children ≥ 2 years of age; extended growth charts are available.
  • Perform a clinical evaluation for overweight and obesity, including a musculoskeletal examination.
  • Routine laboratory testing: at baseline and at least every 2 years [50]
    • 2–9 years of age with obesity: Consider a fasting lipid panel (see “Pediatric dyslipidemia screening”).
    • ≥ 10 years of age
      • All: fasting lipid panel
      • Overweight with risk factors for T2DM: hyperglycemia testing
      • Overweight with risk factors for MASLD: ALT
      • Obesity: hyperglycemia testing and ALT
  • Additional testing [50][51]
    • Decreased linear growth: Obtain endocrine evaluation.
    • Either of the following: Refer for genetic testing.
      • Class 2 obesity or higher at ≤ 5 years of age with hyperphagia and/or a family history of class 2 obesity or higher
      • Developmental delay or other syndromic features

Suspect genetic causes of obesity in children with class 2 obesity or higher at ≤ 5 years of age with hyperphagia and/or other syndromic features. [4][50]

Management [4][52][53]

  • Lifestyle interventions
    • Initiate or refer to intensive health behavior and lifestyle treatment starting at 6 years of age. [4][53]
    • Provide counseling on nutrition; no specific diet is recommended. [54]
    • Provide counseling on regular exercise.
    • Provide counseling on sleep hygiene.
    • Use motivational interviewing to promote behavioral change.
  • Pharmacotherapy: Weight-loss drugs are typically managed by a specialist.
    • 8–11 years of age: Pharmacotherapy may be considered off-label.
    • FDA-approved for long-term use in children ≥ 12 years of age with obesity
      • GLP-1 agonists: liraglutide, semaglutide [4]
      • Orlistat
      • Phentermine/topiramate extended release
    • FDA-approved for short-term use in children > 16 years of age
      • With overweight and weight-related complications or with obesity: phentermine
      • With obesity and no improvement with lifestyle interventions: diethylpropion
  • Bariatric surgery: Refer all patients ≥ 13 years of age with class 2 obesity and higher to a surgical center for evaluation. [32][55]

Overweight and obesity in pregnancy [31]

Preconception

  • Recommend waiting to attempt conception until:
    • 12–24 months after bariatric surgery [38]
    • ≥ 2 months after discontinuation of GLP-1 agonists [56]
  • Prepregnancy counseling should include:
    • Discussion of obesity-related complications in pregnancy [38]
    • Recommendation for weight loss before conception [31]
  • See “Preconception care” for additional information.

Pregnancy

  • At the initial prenatal visit, perform prenatal screening for comorbidities, e.g.:
    • Diabetes screening for overweight with risk factors for T2DM or obesity
    • Screening for OSA
    • Studies for weight-related complications (if not already obtained)
  • Assess for other risk factors for VTE; see “Prevention of DVT in pregnancy and postpartum.” [57]
  • For post-bariatric surgery patients, consider: [58]
    • Studies for micronutrient deficiencies (e.g., thiamine, folate, vitamin B12) early in pregnancy
    • Alternative hyperglycemia tests if a malabsorptive procedure was performed
    • A multivitamin in addition to a prenatal vitamin (limit daily vitamin A intake to 5000 IU)
    • Early referral to a dietitian
  • Weight management
    • Encourage lower recommended weight gain during pregnancy.
      • Overweight: 15–25 lb (6.8–11.3 kg)
      • Obesity: 11–20 lb (5–9.1 kg)
    • Pharmacotherapy and bariatric surgery are contraindicated.
  • Counsel patients with obesity that prenatal ultrasound has decreased sensitivity in detecting fetal abnormalities.
  • Consider earlier antepartum fetal surveillance based on prepregnancy BMI classification. [59]
    • Class 2 obesity: weekly starting at 34 0/7 weeks' gestation
    • Class 3 obesity: weekly starting at 37 0/7 weeks' gestation
  • See “Prenatal care” for additional information.

Obesity-related complications during pregnancy comprise maternal complications (e.g., pregnancy loss, gestational diabetes, preeclampsia, cesarean delivery, postpartum hemorrhage) and fetal complications (e.g., neural tube defects, hydrocephalus, anatomic abnormalities). [31]

Delivery and postpartum [31]

  • Individualize the decision for vaginal or cesarean delivery, and for induction of labor.
  • Consult anesthesiology prior to labor or in early labor.
  • For patients with obesity who undergo cesarean delivery, consider postpartum DVT prophylaxis with LMWH in addition to routine pneumatic compression devices. [57]
  • See “Postpartum care” for additional information.

Pharmacotherapy for obesity is contraindicated during pregnancy and breastfeeding due to the risk of adverse effects in the fetus or infant. [6][25]

  • One-Minute Telegram 57-2022-2/3: Intermittent fasting effective for weight loss
